A change is coming to the 2024 Ontario Building Code that will affect office spaces with convenience stair arrangements. The current OBC allows for an opening between floors limited to not more than 10m2 in area, but this will be removed in the new code. As provinces and cities begin to embrace increased density, it's crucial to reconsider outdated regulations that are standing in the way of homes being built. Single-stair buildings represent a promising housing type that could quickly flourish with the right support. This topic is explored in today's The Globe and Mail, with details on BC's intentions to update building rules to unlock the potential of gentle density homes. It highlights the need to relax the requirement for multi-unit residential buildings in Canada over two storeys to have two separate exit staircases. Small Housing's recent Case Study report delves into this very topic, showcasing the emerging movement across Canada to amend the National Building Code for single-egress residential buildings. Leading this movement are LGA Architectural Partners and David Hine, advocating for the allowance of single-egress buildings up to six storeys above grade. At Small Housing, we‚Äôre keenly observing this space. Greater design flexibility could be pivotal in making gentle density housing projects financially viable.
